step one- get eggs
step two- get ice-cream
step three- boil egg
step four- eat ice-cream
step five- get food colouring
step six- get water
step seven- mix food dye and water
step eight- plop egg in
step nine- buy decorated eggs
step ten- throw away boiled eggs

top_comment.text:
In my home country, we wrap the eggs in onion skins and then boil them in 
water. Sometimes we add tea to it, to add some extra color to the eggs. The 
trick is to add a few layers of different sized fragments of onion skin, so 
that the egg is completely covered in them, while securing them with a 
string. You can wrap the egg in lace or net before adding the onion skins. 
That way you can get nice patterns. You can also place different herbs or 
small leaves under the onion skins. The result should be something like 
these:

http://3.bp.blogspot.com/_OLlvbtRMI5I/S7qFtiRIzjI/AAAAAAAAAt4/V9U26by_A7k/s1600/DSC07654.JPG
http://spi4uk.itvnet.lv/upload/articles/33/335919/images/Krasotas-olas-17.jpg
﻿

top_comment.text:
For the first one we did something similar in art class only not with eggs. 
You get a tray, fill it with shaving cream, get liquid water colors and 
drizzle them around, and use a chopstick or pencil and make a design. Then 
you take a piece of paper and lay it on the shaving cream and press down on 
the areas you want. Gently peel it off from the side, and lay it down cream 
side up on a table. Take a ruler and scrape the shaving cream off and you 
have the same design u made! It's called marbling! ﻿

comments.text:
Actually, I have colored eggs in onion skins my whole life. Everyone in my 
home country color Easter eggs in onion skins. 
Turns out awesome if you put some little flowers, leaves or rice on a wet 
egg, tie it in cheese cloth and then boil the eggs in water with onion 
skins. Pretty. 
I have never heard of just putting eggs in the boiled/colored water and 
waiting for them to color. Just put them in, boil 7-10 minutes and they're 
ready. They should taste just like regular boiled eggs... Even if they 
crack in the pot, they have never tasted like anything else than eggs.

top_comment.text:
I once dyed eggs by cracking the shell from (boiled) eggs then with the 
shell still on put it in some strong not to hot not to cold tea. Let it sit 
overnight. Then the next day remove them from the tea, remove the shell (be 
careful not the to rip the skin of the egg) and then you got some awesome 
marbled egg shit going on. ﻿

For nice red eggs, get yourself a freshly killed corpse (a dog or large 
squirrel would do nicely), next hard boil your eggs, then simply place the 
eggs inside the body, and make sure that the entrails cover it 
completly.... Wait for about an hour, and voila. Red eggs.﻿

captions.text: What's up, Rob here
Man Vs Pin Egg Edition
So I was making some Easter eggs and decided to use some of the suggestions you were leaving in the comments
Goblingwim suggested this pin, dying Easter eggs with natural dyes like coffee and onion skins
Chochii and Megan asked if the shaving cream egg dying technique actually works
And Luisa is curious how these fabric silk dyed eggs will come out
Me too.
First up, I hard boiled some eggs
Then  started with the shaving cream dying pin.
In a glass pie dish I'm throwing down a one to two inch layer of cream
Now I'm using Cool Whip for this because I don't want crazy shaving cream chemical *BLEEP* getting on my eggs
It's supposedly works just the same
Then I grabbed some food coloring, which probably has some crazy chemical *Bleep* In it anyways
and applied small drops of each color randomly on top of the cream
Alright, ready for some awesomeness?
I took out a chop stick and just started playing around making cool swirls of color
And..cool designs..and really just having a little too good of a time
I honestly don't even give a *Bleep* how the eggs turn out at this point
'Cause this was worth it all by itself
Once finished I added a couple of eggs and began rolling them around in the cream
Now I thought this part was gonna be a little more exciting..but..
It was really just messy, kinda uneventful
Once I got the eggs all covered I set those aside and began to work on my silk tie fabric eggs
I acquired a couple of ties, took them apart carefully, I cut off a piece large enough to wrap around an egg
Then placed the fabric print side up and placed a raw egg directly in the middle
Wrapping it up like so
I twisted a twist-tie around it and then took a piece of cheese cloth and wrapped it up a second time
And again, twisted it together
You put the second bit of fabric around it I guess to hold the color in
Or something like that, so just be sure to do that
I repeated that process to a second egg then added them both an enameled pot
Along with some water and vinegar and proceeded to hard boil them for roughly
about 30 minutes
Next up, the natural egg dying pin
Alright let's get through this
Coffee: I brewed one strong cup, added a tablespoon of white Vinegar, and added my egg
Tumeric: Took one tablespoon of tumeric, added it to one cup of hot, boiling water, stirred, added some white vinegar
Added my egg
Then I started to prepare my vegetables for the rest which requires some cooking
I diced up some beets, which are already dying everything in their path
I shredded half a head of red cabbage and lastly peeled the skins off from two yellow onions
I put them all in separate pots, added two cups of water to each one, brought them all to a boil
Then let simmer for about 20-30 minutes
Once finished I poured everything into mason jars, and then added 2 tablespoons of white vinegar
to each
Followed by my egg
And then I just let them sit there, doing their thing for about an hour or so before
I pulled them back out
Alright, let's check out the final products here
Whipped Cream Eggs:
I took them outta there, washed them off, and after all that they looked pretty cool
Kinda like a marbled tye-dye-ish kinda color
Not as dark as I thought they would be but still pretty decent
I took the eggs wrapped with the silk ties out of the water, let em cool off and unwrapped them
And I had to admit that these are pretty *BLEEPING* sweet
The cheese cloth caused this crazy Matrix pattern on the eggs which I thought was pretty cool
Now it doesn't look the fanciest around where you kinda twist-tied everything together,
But then that just becomes the back of the egg, so don't even worry about it
Alright, lastly, the natural Dyes
Coffee: Alright, it's brown, as expected
Tumeric: This came out a nice solid yellow, nothing to complain about
The Beets: Now, they tuned this egg red, obviously, however the color was almost like a film
Covering the egg so the more that you kinda touched it the *BLEEPIER* it looked
Same goes for the red cabbage
It turned the egg this cool blue color, but get's messed up once you start to touch it
The yellow onion actually took this egg as far as orange, which was kinda unexpected
Thought it was gonna be yellow...no film, no nothing
All in All, pretty good looking set of eggs
Better than not having colored Easter eggs
That's for Damn sure
Got a favorite Egg dying trick of your own?
Tell us about it in the comments below.
Leave any other pins of interest that you may find down there as well.
We'll see you next week

title: 3 DIY Easter Egg Pins from Pinterest - Man Vs. Egg #13
